description:
Semicossyphus pulcher, commonly known as the California sheephead, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Labridae, or wrasses. It is found in the eastern Pacific Ocean, ranging from central California to the Gulf of California in Mexico.

The California sheephead is a distinctive-looking fish, characterized by its large, protruding lips and a prominent forehead. It can grow up to 76 cm (30 inches) in length and can live for over 50 years. The species exhibits sexual dimorphism, with males typically being larger and more colorful than females.

Semicossyphus pulcher is an important component of the kelp forest ecosystem, where it serves as a top predator, feeding on a variety of invertebrates such as sea urchins, crabs, and mollusks. The species plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of the kelp forest community by controlling the populations of these herbivorous organisms.

The California sheephead is also of commercial and recreational importance, with the species being targeted by both commercial and recreational fisheries. Conservation efforts are in place to ensure the sustainability of the species, as it is vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation.
